column11: Review Text

This is a very well preserved buddha statue.  You can clearly see all the details still, even so far as a strap line on the shoulder. It was in the middle of the woods which made the whole setting even better for me personally. It is worth having a look at.
That is a most emotional stone statue in the ancient city of anuradhapura kindom and also hugs ancient values at there
This buddha statue is large.  It is thought to date from 4th century AD.  However old it is, it is an impressive piece of stonework.  Very busy so choose the time of your visit

This statue of seated Buddha is within the Abhayagiri Dagoba complex and is included within the $30 Anuradhapura cultural ticket and you get your token for the statue ripped off when you enter the complex. Its a short and easy cycle ride from the main pagaoda and you can park your bike up at the main car park, from where you walk by a large number of market stalls before reaching the statue. The statue itself is relatively small and there is a rope on the floor where your ticket is inspected again and you may enter (without shoes) for a closer look. You can also see quite well from outside the area too. The statue attracts tourists and worshipers alike which is good to see.  A visit doesn't take long and I'm glad we didn't make a specific trip as it doesn't quite warrant one if you are short of time in Anuradhapura.

The statue resembles the meditating Buddha sitting in Siddhasana and palms turned up, right palm almost on top of left palm!. Samadhi statue which is 8 feet tall is made of granite entirely and is a wonder to followers and worshipers. The statue also symbolizes Dhayana Mudra. The posture of meditation of this Statue is a popular for learning of meditation. It was done during the 3rd or the 4th century. It is made out of dolomite marble and stands 7 feet 3 inches in height ! There is another statue similar close by but it's right arm is broken !
Very nice statue of Buddha in a sitting position. Holy place so no shoes. Set inside a huge complex that dates back over two thousand years.
Well, it’s a certainly a statue of buddha and he’s certainly sitting down so I guess it does what it says on the tin.

Every one must visit. It's all about fine art work made out of single piece of rock. Even Jawaharlal Nehru has chapter photograph of the samadhi Buddha statue and pray during the freedom struggle of India.
This is another Buddha statue. Take off your shoes before you get close. I was expecting something more spectacular but it was not coloured, or as big as I expected.

From my Blog: I approached the statue, and to be honest was not as impressed as I thought I’d be. The realist in me saw it as a basic statue, while the traveller in me scolded myself for judging this as merely a place to visit while dismissing the spiritual power this site holds for so many. As I walked off, in the corner of my eye I saw two boys who could not be more than 9 years old playing cricket between two small temple ruins. I took a moment to let where I was hit me. How many times in your life do you have the privilege of being allowed into another religions sacred grounds? How often in your life do you see children playing amongst ruins built thousands of years ago?

The Samadhi ( means in deep meditation) Status which belongs to the 4th - 3rd century BC is the work of an anonymous master - sculptor of the Anuradhapura period who has breathed life into a solid rock. Here, the Buddha is depicted in the Dhyana Mudra, The posture of meditation. This unique piecs of sculpture, was fallen to the ground when re-discovered in 1886. It is 7 feet 3 inches in height and is a depiction of the spiritual purity and serenity of Load Buddha.
This Buddha statue is considered a masterpiece of sculpture. Don't miss going to the nearby sacred Sri Maha Bodhi tree as well.

Although tourists may not be especially impressed with yet another Lord Buddha statue, this site is important for locals and worth visiting as you explore various pilgrimage spots in Sri Lanka.  So it's not to be overlooked. You can research later to discover additional layers of meaning for this site.
It is a Buddha.  It isn’t the biggest, thought it is supposed to be the most exquisite in Sri Lanka.  I didn’t think so, but it’s worth a visit if you are in the neighbourhood
This is another beautiful temple area to visit.The Buddha statue in the middle. The surrounding area has shady trees .
this statue of Buddha is situated in a small area but important to see.  Remember that shoes and hats are not allowed in the temple vicinity.

Samadhi Statue of Lord Buddha is worshiped by lots of local and international tourists since from the past. It is another destination that should be toured or visited in Sri lanka instead of relaxing your mind.Looming over the entire site of Mahamevnawa Park in Anuradhapura, Samadhi Statue is situated in the middle of the Park. This enviable statue possesses a deep meditation and the position of Lord Buddha at the first Enlightenment on his way to Nirvana. The statue can be easily found in the East from the Abhayagiri Dagoba, on the south west of the Sacred Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi and on the shore of Tissa Wewa. Presently it is covered with a metal roof over the statue. The statue takes you to the ancient skilled architectural and knowledge in Sri Lanka around 3rd and 4th century. Yet the government authorities found the Samadhi statue in 1886 it had been fallen down from the seated place. The nose of the statue had to be reconstructed. But it took an artificial appearance to the Statue. The government authorities had to place it properly and conserve it. Otherwise, it would have vanished.
It is inside the park. and you can sit and stay peaceful. wonderful art craft. i liked Buddha statues in Sri Lanka, they are different then those seen in Thailand.
The tuktuk driver took me to this place, and i really liked it. Its quite calm and serene in the middle of the forest.
Visited this as part of our tour of the complex.  Our group was beginning to flag in the heat but I was glad we made it to this statue as it has a real spiritual feel  to it.
The Samadhi statue, depicts the Dhyana Mudra of Lord Buddha (a posture of meditation). This is situated in Mahamevna Park.

Samadhi Buddha Statue is situated in 'Mahamewna Uyana' Anuradhapura. It is situated so close to Abhayagiri Stupa. Samadhi Buddha Statue is an amazing sculpture created in Anuradhapura era. It is carved of single granite stone. Tranquillity of the mind of Lord Buddha is so cleverly shown by the facial expressions of the statue. And therefore, it has become a major tourist attraction in Anuradhapura. This is a must visit place in Anuradhapura. Parkng spaces are available and there are few food and souvenir shops also.
The simplicity of this sculpture brings you back to the basics of life.  When you observe the buddhist pilgrims, yu become quit and respectful.

This is located in Mahamevana Uyana and believed to be one of the great creations of sculpture .  It belong to the Abeygiriya period of the 3rd or 4th century of Sri Lanka’s history. It is not known in whose period of rule, it was sculptured but is thought to be one of four. Similar statues facing the North, South, East and West- this faces North are found. The Samadhi statue is symbolic of the tranquility of mind, with no attraction or repulsion from the world outside to disturb. The palace is way back to thousands of years and at the heart of the Anuradhapura ruins. The visitor will be able to see the best Sri Lankan craftsmanship. This statue of Lord Buddha is made in a way that it depicts different emotions of life, when looked from different angles.  This is a great creation which reveals the ancient Sri Lankan people's talent. Wonderful and it is really worth to visit this place. The budda statute believed to be depicting a expression call Samadhi or peaceful. The time scale of building this statue is unknown. There had four statues and the centre had a Bodhisattva tree. Now only this statue is only founs.  Bodhisattva tree also not found there now. This statue's nose was recreated because invaders destroyed the nose. This statue has interesting views.  When you are looking to the face it looks deep meditation. When you are looking from the left side of the face looks like Buddha is smiling or happy. When seen from the right side it looks like Buddha is sad or worried. It is a masterpiece. The master who carved this statue is a great master. Left half of the lips of the Lord Buddha, is little longer and right half of the lips little shorter. This statue also of very different style one. They are; happy sad and diddle moods of the face if you look at it from 3 sides. This Buddha is beautiful though not as large as the Gal Vihara  Buddhas at Polonnaruwa, but perfect and peaceful. You can buy flowers on the way to leave as an offering. This is an active place of worship with many  Sri Lankans than tourists come for worshiping . The atmosphere is tranquil and spiritual. The tranquillity in the surroundings is miraculous! It might look like the Buddha statues that one might have seen anywhere else, but a close look will reveal much more. The smooth art of making an ordinary stone into an incarnation of Samadh , the ultimate peace is really visible here.  It is more to be seen as work of art with a meaning rather than just an attraction. The Buddha is depicted in the position of the Dhyana Mudra, the posture of meditation associated with his first Enlightenment. Just looking at the statue brings in calmness and serenity into your soul. It also is situated in a very calm surrounding. Samadhi Statue is a must stop for all visitors to Anuradhapura.

This is one of the minor sites ogf the ancient city of Anuradhapura. If you cycle around, this is very near the Moonstone and other of the sites. It's a place of worship, so your knees should be covered, and shoes must be taken off.

Next to Twin bath we visited this place . Large forested area with many buildings ruins where lot of granite pillars standing. There is a guard there to tell us to remove shoes to go near samadhi statue. Peaceful place to visit

Like most of the sites, the statue is located in an enormous area full of smaller and bigger sites, all of which has it´s own history. The Samadhi statue is thought to be constructed in the 3rd or 4th century. Found on (in?) the ground in the late 1800s, it is a well preserved statue in marble with a broken nose. The statue itself is surrounded by several old ruins, many of which still remains to be uncovered

Maybe you think this is just one more Buddha statue. Our driver told us to take two pictures from either side and compare. If you do this you will find out about one of the specifics of this statue - apart from the fact that it belonged to one of the largest complexes in Anuradhapura.

This buddah is an early example of Sinhalese carving and is very famous amongst the local people. Here is buddah is sitting in a meditation position- a classic pose. The buddah is in good condition despite being carved out of limestone, and now is sitting under a concrete roof. It was thought to be one of four statues but all that remains of the are a set of legs!

It is said in many guidebooks that this is the most sublime statue of Buddha in Sri Lanka.  Well, I wouldn't go that far, but it is a lovely statue nonetheless.  Worth a stop, especially if you enjoy ancient Buddhist art.
This is an impressive and well done sculpture of budha in his lotus position. Well worth a visit together with the other items in its vicinity
This is one of the best-loved expressions of the Buddha meditating in Sri Lanka.  Dating from the 4th century CE, it is a timeless evocation of world transcendence.

The Samadhi posture statue of Buddha is considered to be the  finest one in Srilanka. It is of 3rd/4th century period. The 7 feet statue has stood the test of time and is a holy place. The statue presents three different views when seen through over three directions. It is situated in the middle of Mahamevnawa Park in Anuradhapura,This meditate pose of Lord Buddha is called Dhyana Mudra, sitting cross legged and upturned palms placed one over the other on the lap. It is said that the eyes of Buddha are unique in that no where in the world such an arrangements could be seen. A  relatively calm atmosphere when I visited this place on 27.9/2017 in the evening.A serene experience indeed.
It just looks old but it's one of the oldest around and a model for the classic pose.  Very popular with Sri Lankans.

As part of the entrance fee , I hoped for more than an average Buddhist statue . It may well look happy and sad from different angles but it appeared just another Buddhist statue to me and I wondered what all the hype is about .

An amazingly important statue in either religious or a sculpture perspective. The Samadhi Buddha statue reflects the peaceful state of the mind while showing the skills of the craftman who created the wonder centuries ago.

Supposed to be the most exquisite Buddha image found in Sri Lanka. It is sculptured in Gupta style and belongs to the period between 5 - 6 centuries A.D. Probably this image may have been gilt and studded with jewels. The image is in Samadhi posture and seated on Virasana. A must visit place.

Samadhi Buddha statue is considered one of the best crafts made during the Anuradhapura era.the Buddha is depicted in the position of the Dhyana Mudra, the posture of meditation associated with his first Enlightenment. Whether the Buddha's Enlightenment was the experience technically called samadhi, or some other phenomenon, may depend upon the philosophical allegiance of the believer. In the Dhyana Mudra the Buddha sits cross-legged with his upturned palms placed one over the other on his lap. This position is universally known throughout the Buddhist world, and this statue is therefore one of the most typical pieces of Buddhist sculpture.
Samadhi Buddha statue is another amazing creation of the ancient Sri Lankan artists. Samadhi Statue is a must see place in the Anuradhapura trip

Statue got its name because kindness of Lord Buddha flows through the half closed eyes. It displays the Dhyana Mudra of Lord Buddha. It is made during the Anuradhapura Era (3rd or the 4th century). It displays three different expressions when you look at the statue from the front, left side and from right side.

Governments main job is to rip the tourist off and even the officials behave this way, arrogant and not customer oriented at all. It is all about money here. The price for tourist RP 3500 compared to almost nothing paid by locals. You have to pay that to be able to access the entire area. Not worth the money. "My generous donation will help you preserve the heritage" (as stated on the ticket) however should the locals be also interested to take a part? After you pay the entrance fee almost nothing is in English. You have to open google to get at least some information. Also you would expect at least basic English knowledge of the staff if you charge this entrance fee. We had a disagreement with the staff I took as 15 mins to find someone who can speak basic English. Or at least clean up at the historical sites from all the garbage. I can't really see here that the money is actually going in the heritage. Didn't buy it. Also to be honest there is not that much you can see for the money here unless you are really a big history fan or Buddhist.
The statue is of high importance to all  Buddhists. Photographs are allowed, but you cannot face your back towards the statue. It is said that the statue is 8 feet high.
Blessed and very nice experience. Anyone who's interested in history of Sri Lanka and Buddhism should visit this place since its close by to all the other religious places.

This is a religious place, so shoes off, legs and shoulders covered. Locals make offerings here, so it is a place to respect. The statue is interesting as is the thought there used to be four of them, the second is only partially there. Worth a visit as part of the Anuradhapura visit.
You can see different facial expressions from each angles. That's the importance of this great statue. A must visit place
Buddha in Sri Lanka more or less you always see in the reclining position while this statue is the sitting position in dhayana mudra. A very beautiful statue.
Samadhi Statue of Lord Buddha is worshipped by lots of local and international tourists since the past

It is made out of dolomite marble and stands 7 feet 3 inches (2.21 meters) in height and it is considered one of the best sculptures in the Anuradhapura era.If you are going to Anuradhapura don't miss this.Also go there when it is morning or evening.Coz you can sit there for a while meditating.The experience is tremendous. It is thought to be done during the 3rd or the 4th century and it was found in the present location in 1886 fallen to the ground with damages to the nose.
Nice statue in a tranquil spot - under some trees. You have to walk through the souvenir  market to get to it
In SL you can think.  Another Buddha statue.  Another temple.  Does this one stand out.  No.  Was it worth seeing.  I guess.

Rhis was built thousands years ago. The statue depicts the calmness of Buddha. When he was in jail, former Indian prime minister Nehru had a large photo of this statue in his cell as the statue was a symbol of calmness.
Advisable to go early in the morning as possible or late in the evening as with the hot sun it's difficult to visit these places
I most recommend this place to every Buddhist people in the whole world to see how they created Lord Buddha's great Kindness.
More popular with buddhists. Close to the Anuradhapura historical sites. Unknown when this statue was built. But the archeological department of Sri Lanka has restored this stature in 1960.
Beautiful statue - so serene and what a marvellous unspoilt setting - not many tourist around so peaceful and quiet
We visited this place while roaming around the stupas of Anuradhapura. It is a nice statue, but is also something you can give a miss if you are short on time.
A significant Buddha statue, highly praised by the locals, although with little interest to the non-religious traveller.

Stopped at the edge of a small village and had to walk past a myriad of shops, many tourist until at the far end an isolated statue of a Buddha, covered with 4 posts holding up roof and protecting the Buddha from the elements. Man asking us to remove shoes as we approached. However ground very mucky and rough even for socks and we observed quite clearly some 30 metres away.
Must visit place in Sri Lanka. One of the amazing sculptures in the world. Situated in Ancient city of Anuradhapura.

It's pretty presumptuous to review this statue! It is off to the side of the main stupa, so you have to make a five minute walk through beautiful woods interspersed with ruins. The statue used to be in the open air many years ago. Still pretty wondrous.
The Buddha statue has a nice stone canopy over it ,is surrounded by lovely trees and part of the Anuradhapura old capital
A decent place to go.  Nothing really great.  Can skip this place if there is scarcity of time. We stopped by for some pics.

Located in a nice park, this Buddha is beautiful. There are plants and trees around which adds to the tranquility one might feel when visiting this place. My tour guide told me to take off my shoes as we approach the Buddha.
Nice gardens and inside a perimeter wall. The statue itself is beautiful but for me it was just another buddha statue.

This seated Buddha statue is reportedly one of the best sculptures of the Anuradhapura era,  and as one of the sacred places at Anuradhapura is a place of devotion. However for non buddhists there is not too much to appreciate.

A very nice construction.  And lovely environment surrounded by many ancient ruins. This and Abayagiriya stupa both can be visited together. Very sheltered place with many trees. A bycicle ride will be ideal. There is parking for larger vehicles. Not very suitable to go after 5.00 p.m
This is a stone statue of the Lord Buddha and this is an ancient monument. All buddhists must visit this place and worship.

This is the finest and spiritually elevating image of Buddha in entire Sri Lanka. From 4th Century AD, the beautiful posture reflect compassion and benign Grace of Buddha in perfection.A must place to visit in Anuradhapura.

The statue has been covered by a ugly concrete roof and surrounded by a similarly inappropriate concrete fence. Both structures digging into layers of archaeological strata and destroying them for ever. Is there a archaeological department in this country? Who approves these nasty new constructions at ancient sites ? Vehicles have to be parked far away. The walk is through a  row of slums selling gaudy Chinese products of psychedelic hues. .

Situated in the Ancient City of Anuradhapura, this is regarded as one of the best piece of art in Sri Lankan history. This statue is carved using a granite rock. There is a famous saying about this statue. That is the face reflects sadness from one side and the happiness from the other side. We visited the place at night. So really beautiful with illumination.
One of many Buddha statues in Sri Lanka but I find them all very calm places that clear the mind. Worth taking in on a general tour of the town.
Well worth a visit while you are in anuradhapura. Remember you can take photos but not with your back facing the statue

When ever I go to Samadhi Budhdha I keep on looking at it for humour and hours. Still not enough. What ever the problem vanish when you  are looking at the Budhda state.  It soothes my mine. It means a lot. You should look at it in different angle. It says many things. It's a calm place. I would like to go there more and more.

SAMADHI BUDDHA Samadhi Buddha is a statue of Mahatma Buddha in Mahameghawana (also called Mahamevnawa) Park in the midst of ancient city of Anuradhapura, near Abhayagiri Monastery. This statue shows Buddha in the posture of Dhiyan Mudra. This 7 feet high statue with Buddha face showing three different moods (plain, sad, smiling) from 3 different sides, is considered one of the best sculpture in ancient history of Sri Lanka, supposed to be carved from dolomite marble in 4th to 6th century AD. It was found at the present place in 1886, fallen on the ground with damaged nose. It was then repaired and erected.
Its near by the twin baths only and a statue of Lord Buddha in Samadhi.. No Photograpghy allowed... You can just see
You can visit their for some photos but remember not to turn your back towards the statue. One of the many buddha statue  you will see in sri lanka.
Shoes and hats off!  Don't turn your back on the Buddha!  The crowds, their devotion and dedication and offerings make this a worthwhile place to visit!

This statue is situated in Anuradhapura city in a place called Mahamevuna Garden. The position Lord Buddha is sitting is called the Dhyana mudra.It will be of real value for people interested in Art & History. This statue is world famous as the  craftsmanship is amazing. Be properly dressed as a mark of respect to Buddhism. Well worth a visit.
Just another buddha ... Its nothing soooo special, made by stone. The locals love this place, so it gets crowdy compared to other places

This statue is not very incredible in itself, but it has a history which is worth noting. An English general would one day during the occupation start shooting at the statue, you can see three patches on the statue where he hit. When the general was shooting suddenly a Tusker (Elephant with tusks) came out of the forest and killed him on the spot. For the Buddhist this shows that the place is utterly sacred.

Nice statue, but you will see much more beautiful statues around sri Lanka. Anuradhapura it self is nice, but all the sights are so scattered that you never have the idea that you are visiting an ancient city. The local people are also living in between the ancient stupas and other sights. You can't blame them but it is a pity of the total experience. We liked other big sights as Sigiriya and Polonnaruwa more mainly because of this.

The air of the place carries a certain serenity. There is silence which isn't dull or gloomy. It's a beautiful place to visit especially if you are a solo traveller looking for a place which is peaceful and happy at the same time.. Perfect for sitting for a while and drifting into thoughtlessness.

A holy place in the area of Abhayagiri Dagoba, very popular with local pilgrims. A marble statue of a seated Buddha with a particular thing: if you look at it from three sides (in front, from right and from left) you will notice three different expressions of the face! Remove your shoes before approaching the statue.
and no pictures with your back to the statue! Fun snacks and lemonade in the walkway outside leading to the carpark.

This statue tells us the story of meditation. When you look at the face of this statue from the left side you will see a sad face, and straight look will show you meditation pause, and then the right view will have smile on the face, therefore Remember to look at the statue in Three directions. This is one of the greatest creations of Sri Lankan history.

Beautiful Buddha statue in a lovely park. Best advice: wear inexpensive flip flops that you can take off easily because you must walk barefoot at these holy places. Don't wear sneakers because 1)they are difficult to take off easily and 2)when it rains, they will be soaked and uncomfortable. Also, don't wear expensive sandals because of the rain/mud. The locals just wear inexpensive sandals and flip flops.

Enjoyed walking to the statue, lots of lovely trees and bird life. Lots of locals meeting and sitting in groups learning how to meditate from the monks. A beautiful scene visually, the white dress of the devotees and the orange robes of the monks seated amongst the trees. Very peaceful setting.
Really enjoyed spending time in Anuradhapura. Samadhie Statue is a must see. Really peaceful place where the locals come.
Its amazing rock statue  of the  loard buddha.  the creator's talents  cannot express words its shows real situation. when we see in front of  this statue our mind too feel relaxed ..
The old city is a must to visit when you are in Sri Lanka! 7 stupa's and a convent ruin where 3500 monks lived is incredible to imagine!
Lord Buddha with historical background is clearly depicted at this place and is quite relaxing and divine location
An ancient Buddha status with three different expressions from each side (front view, left side and right side)

This is the first one of the places you should visit in Anuradhapura. If you are a non Buddhist but love to explore archeological sites this would be another land mark for you. This is a Buddha statue located in the Abhayagiri Stupa complex.  This is a statue of Gautama Buddha in meditation posture or Dhyana Mudra made out of out of dolomite marble and stands 7 feet 3 inches (2.21 metres) in height and width. This belongs to the old Abhayagiri chapter teaching monastery which was built in the 89-77 BC. Old records of Faxian Buddhist monk from china mentioned that this Agayagiri monastary was a huge university at that age with four faculties. This is belongs to one of those faculty. Some of the historical archives give evidence that the king bought a Buddha statue from “Maha Vihara – great monastery located around the “Sri maha Bodhi” temple. So some archeologists clams that this is that statue. The first prime minister of India Javahallal Neru once visited this Buddha statue and said this place gives him inner peace. And he kept a photo graph of this statue also in his residence.

This Buddha statue said to be made of stone is just over 7 feet tall and sits on a square base.. The Buddha is said to be depicted in a state of "Samadhi" which is difficult to translate directly -as a state of intense concentration and deep awareness is fitting. It dates to 2 or 3 AD. When you gaze at the statue, a feeling of calmness and peace overcomes you. The expression on his  face is overpowering. The statue is now protected by a concrete hood which does take away some of the attraction of this most famous meditation statue of the World. The expression as seen by the observer is said to change depending on the angle from it is viewed. It is situated in a beautiful park and the whole atmosphere is one of serenity. It is not too far from the main Dagobas and is well worth a visit. If you go all the way to Anuradhapura to witness the ruins of an ancient and advanced civilisation, you will feel very bad if you miss this amazing statue.

This statue is for the religious only who believe in it's significance. For everyone else it's just a fairly worn statue. It's kind of out of the way and I came along because I was seeing Abhayagiri Dagoba anyway. Otherwise, give it a miss.
Walked through the market stalls (selling mostly tat) to get to this attraction, what a shame. The statue site is well kept and there is a peaceful serene feeling when you are there.

After visiting the buzzing sites of the big dagobas and stupas all day, you may appreciate the peaceful setting of this sacred site. Embedded in a beautiful park, this site invites you to take a breath and mediate while enjoying its beauty. A very good place for a short break in your pilgrim day.

There are 3 Bodhi Tree Shrines at Abayagiri Monastery. This is the 3rd shrine. According to most of the people, this is the most artistic seated Buddha Statue in Sri Lanka. Statue was found in the present location in 1886 fallen to the ground with damages to the nose. It was then erected and the nose was reconstructed by Most Ven. Mapalagama Vipulasara Thero (An artist and sculptor who has gained fame through his sculptures of Buddha statues that are worshiped in many places within Sri Lanka and abroad). It is said that when you look at the face of the statue from three sides they show 3 different features. Looking at the profile of the face from left and right they show a slight sadness and a slightly smiling face on the other. Looking from the front, the face shows neutral features. Do not forget to visit other 2 Bodhi Tree shrines at Abayagiri Monastery.

It was beautiful to visit this site. I reached there and saw a man raking the lotus flowers kept as offerings on the table in front. It was lovely to experience the space as such and walk around it. The statue is beautiful!!
I visited here late afternoon after a monsoon downpour . Quiet and utterly peaceful. Take a while and be in the moment with this elegant understated ancient representation of the Buddha.
This is located in mahamevana Uyana and believed to be one of the great creations of sculpture . The budda statute believed to be depicting a expression call samadhi or peaceful.
Like everything in this historical area of Sri Lanka this statue is well worth a visit. The culture in this area does not dissapoint

When was built this statue unknown. There had four statues and the centre had a Bodhisattva tree. Now only having this statue and Bodhisattva tree also not there. This statue's nose was recreated because invaders destroyed the nose. This statue having interesting views. When you are looking to the face it looks deep meditation. When you are looking from the left side of the face looks like Buddha is smiling or happy. When seen from the right side it looks like Buddha is sad or worried. It is masterpiece. The master who carved this statue is a great master. How he did this effect? Left half of the lips little longer and right half of the lips little shorter. This place aslo having higher energy level and very good place to do meditation.

It's a Buddha statue like many others, but it's old. Since it's near Abhayagiri, you might as well stop to see it on the way. But it's not worth going out of the way to see. A plus is that there are food and drink stalls nearby.
this statue allso very diferant style one. 3 kind of facial exprecions you can see. happy   sade    diddle way from 3 sides

This Buddha is beautiful - not as large as the Gal Vihara Buddhas at Polonnaruwa, but perfect and peaceful.  You can buy flowers on the way to leave as an offering.  This is an active place of worship with many more Sri Lankans than tourists - take shoes and hat off The atmosphere is tranquil and spiritual.
Samadhi Statue is a must stop for all visitors to Anuradhapura. The tranquility in the surroundings is miraculous!

One of the best sculptures I have seen in my life time. It might look like the  Buddha statues that one might have seen anywhere else, but a close look will reveal more. The smooth art of making an ordinary stone into an incarnation of Samadhi , the ultimate peace is really visible here. Its more to be seen as work of art with a meaning rather than just an attraction.

The Samadhi Statue is a statue situated at Mahamevnāwa Park in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka. The Buddha is depicted in the position of the Dhya .na Mudra, the posture of meditation associated with his first Enlightenment,belong to the Abeygiriya period of the 3rd or 4th century of Sri Lanka’s history. It is not known in whose period of rule it was sculptured but is thought to be one of four similar statues facing the North, South, East and West- this faces North. The Samadhi statue is symbolic of the tranquillity of mind, with no attraction or repulsion from the world out side to disturb.

As such this may seem like another Budha Statue in Samadhi state. Probably the Statue at Gal Vihara in Polonnaruwa is more impressive. This place originally had 4 Budha statues facing each direction, with a tree in the middle. Right now only one statue is left out. Though our guide mentioned that Budha looks sad when seen from one side and happy when seen from the other, I was not able to really identify that. Place is considered sacred and hence you need to remove the footwear. Since there are a lot of trees, no need to worry about the hot floor. No Separate tickets.

This is a stunning statue to see up close. As you walk around it, you can see that the expression on Lord Buddha's face changes. Its fascinating and speaks to the great craftsmanship that went into building this statue. Folks come and set flowers before the statue, so its a calm and serene place. Definitely recommend stopping by if you are in the area.
The palace is way back to thousands of years and at the heart of the Anuradhapura ruins. The visitor will be able to see the best Sri Lankan craftsmanship.

This statue of Lord Buddha is made in a way that it depicts different   emotions of life, when looked from different angles. Just looking at the statue brings in calmness and serenity into your soul. It also is situated in a very calm surrounding.

This statue was original one of four that faced in each direction.  Though this one and the base of the one opposite it are all that remains.  It is in a very serene setting and made me feel very humble.  You do have to remove your shoes to walk up the dirt path to it and to walk around the general area.  The neatest thing is that from one side it is frowning and from the other smiling.  Please be respectful when you visit.

This statue is of the Buddha depicted in the position of Dhyana Mudra, the posture of meditation associated with Nirvana. It is a very attractive and culturally important statue carved from granite. Standing around 8 feet in height it is nowhere near as vast as many other similar statues found in the cultural triangle of Sri Lanka but has an elegance and charm that is worthy of a visit. It is located in Mahamevnawa Park in Anuradhapura which in itself is a place of peace and tranquillity.

Mahamevnāwa Park (in the Northern part): you walk by the park and you feel peace and dignity of the place, then you conturn the both granite statues, on the left - a tree with big fruit like a cannonball tree - Couroupita guianensis. Buddhist scriptures tell  the Maya Devi have given birth to Buddha under the shade of a Sala Tree and passed away between two of these trees. Buddha is shown with scented flower petals on his deathbed.

This is an attractive and important statue, especially for the Sinhalese who praise it highly.  The statue is partly restored (the nose) and personally I preferred the samadhi sculpture (and the other statues) at Gal Vihara.

Yeah it is an old Buddha, but it is very small and had us wondering if we were in the right place. As it is near some other sights you might as well take a look but not worth the journey to see it alone.

'Samadhi' is the state of deep contemplation.The Samadhi Statue situated in the ancient Mahamena 'Uyana' (=park) depicts Lord Buddha in a meditative pose. It is said that the late Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru derived strength from looking at a picture of this statue during his imprisonment.

A must vist in Anuradhapura. It's  Of archeological Value dating back to 2000 years. Restored but the present construction of a shade to the statue has spoiled its value. Compared to previous restorations and nowadays modernisation is notable everywhere. But it is spoiling the archeological value of ancient Anuradhapura. It is becoming a concrete jungle with paved pathways landscaped gardens. Loosing its natural beauty.

To some another Buddha, to us it was one of the first Buddhas we saw in Anuradapura and it was where our guide began to explain to us the various poses of the Buddha. It does feel spiritual at this site and I am glad we visited it. It was where we learnt not to have our backsides to Buddha when being photographed (as our guide eloquently put it)
The most Serene atmosphere with less hustle bustle. Great place for meditation. Try to avoid long weekends and full moon poya days.
As a non Buddhist, I didn't find this sandstone statue exceptional. Maybe it's a case of too much within the site. If you are passing through, it's worth a look but not a special effort.

This huge Buddha is a very impressive statue, what a beautiful work. Maybe it's good to see this one before visiting the huge granite statues in Polonnaruwu (Gal Vihara) which are more impressive. But the setting here is beautiful, I visited in the evening, there were no other tourists around, all very peaceful.

Located in Mahamewna park, a very pleasing park with lots of tall trees and comforting breeze from nearby tanks, Samadhi Pratima (meaning statue in English) speaks of ancient aesthetic and architectural skills of Sinhalese people of 3rd BC. From left it gives a feeling of slight sympathy and from right a feeling of happiness. This is a must see site if you love art.

This is just the statue of Buddha in the so called 'Samadhi' position. There are lot of such Samadhi statues in Sri Lanka. Really makes me think how this is different in an way. You'll have to leave your slippers outside and walk on the pathway for quite some distance. The pathway is not that well maintained and can hurt your leg.

The slightly different expressions when looking from one side or the other of the face are intriguing. I didn't pay to much attention to it when I was there, but, as the other reviews say, this is indeed one of the most peaceful buddha statues we have seen in Sri Lanka.

This is the great monument sculpture where the late Indian pri minister Jwahal lal Sri Nerhu got mesmerized for its great  features of peace. When one observe this great statue it cannot be visualized as to how these features and fine lines. had been caved during the 16th BC with primitive tools. Though there are bigger and beautiful statures built at present, the difference is as to how those work men had given life to such a great statue with fine artistic value.

One should not judge holy statues by their artistics value. In this case these ar not totally on par. And it would be much better  and more peacefull not to have to run the gauntlet of shops that reach up to 20 meters from the statue.

This is a must see  A beautiful rendition of the Buddha in Samadhi. As a tourist and not a Buddhist it was still a powerful experience to just stand and contemplate the Buddhas life and the life of his devotees who carved this so many centuries ago for us still to be enjoying. The full Moon festival of Poya meant that there was many Devotees of today visiting this Holy Statue and it was a delight for us to see even small children bringing their offerings. A must see
A famous statue of lord Buddha situated in Mahamewna Uyana in Anuradhapura. Another must see and usually never missed by anyone visiting the city.

I can still see the face on this remarkable representation of the Buddha. He is obviously in deep meditation. If you look from one side he appears to be happy and from the other, he appears to be sad. From the front, he appears to be deeply at peace. A memory to savour.
This large Buddha is carved from limestone and dates from the 4th century AD. Unfortunately the artistry of the figure is compromised by a rather ugly concrete shelter under which it sits.

A beautiful, unusual & serene sculpture depicting the bliss of "Nirvana" by Lord Buddha. It shows the rich heritage of Sri-Lankan sculpture of many years ago. A must see for anybody who visits Anuradhapura.Its a well maintained & clean place, but one must be careful with the Monkeys around the place. Foriegn Tourists are charged to see the Cultural Triangle.
